titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. IV:30. Sunday. Passed a Night almost sleepless, from the great heat. Immediately after rising I walked to the river and bathed. Cardelli was here, still complaining of his grievances— At four in the afternoon, Robert Buchanan and Tom Hellen came to say that Mrs Frye’sinfant was dying of a dysentery— It has been ill since last Wednesday, but we had not heard of it before— Mrs Adams went immediately to her Sisters and left the boys here. Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were here this Evening. At 9 the boys went home, and Mrs Adams came back. The child died between six and seven— Fahrenheit 95. at 4. P.M. and 92. at nine this Evening.

2. IV:30. Bathed in the river, just at Sunrise; but the night itself was so warm, that the walk to and from the river was uncomfortable. The water nearly tepid. With such a temperature of the atmosphere, the sensual pleasure of bathing, and swimming is so great that I should think it would be more practiced— The fact is that in Europe, it is practised by the Great and the wealthy, wherever it is made costly. They travel in England hundreds of miles, and at hundreds, of expence, to places of Sea-bathing; which most of them utterly neglect when they have them at their door— Captain Read of the Hornet arrived this morning with despatches from Mr Forsyth, but without the Treaty, which it is now certain will not be ratified. Read left Madrid the 22d. of June and Cadix the 2d. of July— Mr Calhoun soon afterwards came in to the Office, and I gave him the despatches to peruse; he is to send them to Mr Crawford— Mrs Adams sent for me and I attended the funeral of Mr Frye’schild— It was buried at Georgetown, and the funeral service was performed by Mr Hawley. We took Mrs W. S. Smith home. Captain Read and MrForbes called here this Evening. Fahrenheit 95 this afternoon, and 90 at 9 this Evening. Nature and the capacity of labour bodily and mental sink under it.

3. IV. On the 13th. of August last year I saw Sirius before Sunrise. I inspected the sky this Morning to ascertain if he were now visible— I saw the whole of Orion, and should have seen Sirius rise, but in the quarter where he was to appear there was a thick cloud which intercepted the view of him. Bathed in the river. The extreme heat of the weather partially abated, by a light breeze from the North-East and Northwest, which in the course of the day terminated by a light thunder shower followed by a moderate rain— I took up Mrs W. S. Smith who went to pass the day at her Sister, Mrs Frye’s. Poletica called at the Office. He had called last Evening at my house— His object was to enquire, the news from Spain— I told him— He said he regretted much that he had not arrived here in time to have given Mr Forsyth, a Letter to Tatischeff the Russian Minister at Madrid who had much influence there, for which the English Ambassador Sir Henry Wellesley, and who, if for no other reason than his hatred to the English, would have used every effort to effect the ratification. I told him it was probable a messenger might be sent with despatches to Mr Forsyth, and he might yet have time to write to Tatischeff— He said he would; but then he intimated again the wish that we would accede to the Holy Alliance. Mr Calhoun called at the Office, and we had some conversation, upon the present State of Affairs. It requires deep deliberation, and wisdom from the highest source— I walked home, and made a short Evening.

4. IV: I endeavoured again to observe the rising of Sirius without success. Bathed in the river— I yesterday consulted Dr Huntt upon the thorn in my flesh, which he thinks a moveable, and not dangerous inflammation. The weather having much moderated, I sat again to Mr King— At the Office I wrote to the President, but expecting he may be here, before the Letter can reach him did not enclose the despatches received from Mr Forsyth. Rode home from the Office— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith spent the Evening here.

5. V: Bath in the river. Received Letters from the President, at his Seat in Albemarle; which he is to leave this day, to arrive here next Sunday. Mr Anderson the Comptroller called here to make some enquiries concerning the Salary and Accounts of his nephew, the Consul, late at Tunis, and now at Tripoli. He told me my own account was adjusted, of which he would give me a written notice to-morrow. He says that Pleasonton’s account for monies received on the contingent fund of the Department of State has also been passed and reported
upon, with a balance of upwards of 1200 dollars due by Pleasonton— Visit from Mr Van den Bergh, the applicant from New-York, for the Office of Consul at Marseilles— I stopped at King’s for the purpose of sitting, but he was engaged with a Lady—Mrs M’Kenney. Called at Crawford’s and Calhoun’s Offices to shew them the President’s Letter, and had a long conversation with them, on the state of Affairs, with a view of ascertaining their opinions what is to be done with Spain— My own is for measures of the most decisive character. They appear to be not quite prepared for them, particularly Crawford. Indeed our Relations with Spain, and the Peace of the Country are thrown into a more dangerous and fearful Crisis than they ever have been. Who can foresee the consequences of any political measure? A responsibility is again cast upon me, under which all my natural powers would sink, and the issue of which may be the worst possible— Mrs Adams spent the Evening at her Sister Smith’s and came home very ill— The Viscount de Quabeck, Dr and Mrs Thornton, Mr & Mrs Bulfinch, and Cardelli were here in the course of the Evening.

6. IV: The moon was full at 10. last Evening; and I found the tide high this Morning at seven O’Clock. This I fix as the hour at which the flood tide is at its height at the Potowmack Bridge, at New and full moon— It was this Morning a high tide— At the Office, Mr William Taylor came with a Mr Eastin, who solicits an appointment as agent at Port-au Prince— Mr R. Cutts came to enquire about the house in which he lives, and which I have bargained to purchase of A. Way— Cutts’s Lease, and mine of the house in which I now live, both expire on the 30th. of September. I have thought of going into that house on the first of next October, but Cutts wishes to keep the house where he is another year, and I agreed this day that he should keep it; at the Rent which he now gives; and upon Condition that in the course of the year, I shall build a Coach-house, and Stable on a part of the lot behind the house— Cutts wanted to take the house only till the Spring to which I did not assent. So he said he would send me his answer to-morrow. I was employed almost all the Office hours in a final examination of the Manuscripts, for the Journals of the Convention of 1787 to be published at Boston— Rode to and from my Office. Spent part of the Evening with Mr Calhoun— Mrs Adams is yet unwell, and was bled by Dr. Huntt.

7. V: Bath— It was the proper Spring tide, 36 hours after the full moon; yet was not so high a tide as that of yesterday Morning. I sat about an hour to King, but the heat of the weather was so overpowering that I could not sit longer— Captain Read of the Hornet was at the Office, and Mr Smith Thompson the Secretary of the Navy, who arrived here yesterday— Mr Neal came as an applicant for the Office of Register of Wills, vacant by the death of Dr Blake— Mr D. Brent was absent from the Office— There was a very sudden thunder gust this afternoon, followed by a copious shower— As usual in this climate it left the atmosphere more sultry than before it came on.

8. V: Reading the Newspapers this morning, I saw in the Boston Patriot of Tuesday last a Card from my father, to the Inhabitants of Quincy, making his acknowledgments to them, for their active exertions, though unsuccessful to save his property from the Conflagration at Mount Wollaston, on Thursday the 29th. of July. I had heard nothing of this before— Bathed in the Potowmack: the last time for this succession of morning tides. Mr George Hay called here to enquire, if I had heard since Thursday from the President. He had doubts whether he would arrive here this day— Cardelli came in great distress having been dismissed from his employment at the Capitol, by the Commissioner Coll. Lane, who says the appropriation for this year is exhausted and he has no money. I resumed for a very short time the preparation of my Report upon Weights and Measures, which has been long, very long inexcusably neglected by me, to my great self-reproach— After dinner, Mr Calhoun called upon me, and rode with me to the President’s house. We found him returned from his Journey; with his companions, Mr Gouverneur, and Lieutenant Monroe. He is in good health, though much exhausted by a journey of 5000 Miles all South of this Latitude, and almost all in Summer— While we were there, the Secretary of the Navy, Mr Thompson came in— We made our visit of about an hour— I took Calhoun home to his house— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith spent the Evening here.

9. V: Though I omitted the morning bath, I gained nothing of profitable time. Since the beginning of July the heat of the weather renders all occupation after the dusk of evening impracticable— For neither windows closed nor candlelight are tolerable— I found it so last year, and the same at present. This throws my daily newspaper reading over to the Morning, two hours of which at least it absorbs every day. Then assorting the papers, half an hour or an hour for the diary, and the trifling propensity which I have not energy of mind to overcome, swallow the time, from five in the Morning till noon— The irrevocable hours are gone, and nothing, or next to nothing useful is performed— I called this Morning at the President’s— He appointed a Cabinet Meeting for to-morrow, at Noon, and asked me to call on him before the Meeting. He also fixed on Wednesday at one O’Clock to receive Mr Poletica the Russian Envoy, to deliver his Credentials, and Mr. Antrobus, the English Charge d’Affaires, to deliver Letters from the Prince Regent— At the Office Mr Lomonosoff came with a Note from Mr Poletica, enclosing a copy of his Credential Letter, and asking an Audience of the President to deliver it— Mr William Taylor and Mr Eastin the applicant for an appointment as commercial agent at Port-au-Prince came to enquire if he could obtain it. I asked Eastin, if he expected a Salary— He said yes— I told him that might raise a difficulty, as there was an application for the Office by a person who asked no Salary, and as the fund from which alone the Salary can be paid was not able to bear the charge— O’Brien wrote me one of his crazy nautical dictionary Letters about his Claim; and Cathcart sent me one on Saturday, importuning for money on a presumptive balance in his favour, which he has a very doubtful pretension to claim— Mrs Susan B. Clark, with her infant daughter came to pass some time with us this Evening— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were here.

10. IV: I have been watching every morning since the first of this Month to observe the rising of Sirius, and this Morning discovered him for the first time, coming from a cloud, and less than five minutes above the horizon— I saw him till he was about twenty minutes risen, when he vanished from the vision of the naked eye. It was half past four when he rose, and I conclude that if the horizon had been clear I might have seen him about the 5th.— There was a Cabinet Meeting at the President’s from noon till four O’Clock. He proposed two Questions for consideration—1. Whether in the Event of the Non-ratification of the Spanish Treaty, at the Meeting of Congress next December, it will be proper for the President to recommend to Congress that authority should be given to the Executive to take possession of Florida—and 2. Whether a special Messenger should be sent immediately with Instructions to Mr Forsyth, and what those Instructions should be. Upon the first there was no diversity of opinion. The obligation of the King of Spain to ratify the Treaty was by all present considered as perfect— His full power to Onis being unlimited, and containing without reserve the promise, without reserve to ratify whatever he should sign and conclude. It was unanimously agreed that it would be proper for the Executive to recommend to Congress the measure of taking possession, and it was observed that from the experience in the case of the late war with England, Congress would not adopt the measure without such Recommendation. It was also agreed that a Messenger should be despatched with Instructions to Forsyth— The President inclined to the opinion that he should be ordered to declare that the Ratification of Spain would be accepted, even after the lapse of the stipulated six Months, if received here before the Meeting of Congress in December; but that if refused or delayed until that time, a full communication would be made to Congress of all the transactions relating to the Treaty, with a recommendation that they should immediately authorize the occupation of Florida; not as an act of hostility to Spain; but as an assertion of our own right, rendered necessary by the breach of faith on the part of Spain— Mr Crawford thought Forsyth should be instructed to demand the immediate ratification, and in the event of non-compliance to ask for his Passports.— Calhoun on the contrary thought he should be instructed to remain at Madrid; and not even come away upon leave of absence, leaving T. Brent as Chargé
d’Affaires, as he is authorised to do, and intended— The President embraced this opinion also. He thought that to order Forsyth to demand his Passports would be equivalent to a declaration of War, which would not be advisable; as his intention to limit measures of force entirely to the assertion of our rights, explicitly disclaiming at the same time all intentions of general hostility— Crawford adhered steadily to his idea of instructing Forsyth to ask for his Passports and come away. He thought it could not be taken as a declaration of War, but that it would intimidate the Spanish Cabinet and compel them to an immediate ratification— He was however alone in his opinion, upon which I said very little, leaving the discussion to Crawford and Calhoun— I thought Forsyth’s Instructions should be, offering still to receive and transmit the Spanish Ratification, to state that, if not given, the President would make a full communication to Congress on the Subject, without saying that he should recommend the immediate occupation of Florida, but leaving that to be inferred by the Spaniards themselves. I thought a direct menace would be less dignified as regards Spain, and would leave the matter more free for debate in Congress—where umbrage might be taken, if the executive held out a threat to a foreign Nation, of that which it could not without express authority from Congress carry into Execution. This view was finally approved by the President, and I was charged to prepare the draft of an Instruction to Forsyth, and also Letters to A. Gallatin, R. Rush, and G. W. Campbell, that suitable communications may be made to the Governments of France, Great-Britain and Russia, of the measures which we shall probably pursue. I was authorised also to communicate with Poletica and de Neuville on the subject— There was very little debate, and entire good humour throughout the Meeting. Crawford and Calhoun, were the only members of the Administration present besides myself. Mr Thompson the Secretary of the Navy was detained at his lodgings by illness; and Mr Wirt the Attorney General was absent at Richmond— We dined at the President’s, and had a discussion at table about the Bible. I took a long evening ramble with Calhoun.

11. IV: Saw Sirius rise from the horizon in a position to mark very precisely his place— Went to the President’s, shortly before One O’Clock. Mr Poletica came with Mr Lomonossoff— I introduced Poletica to a private Audience, where he delivered his Credential Letter, and made a short complimentary address, which the President answered with equal brevity— Afterwards Poletica went and introduced Lomonossoff to the President, but I did not accompany them— Immediately after they had withdrawn, Mr Antrobus came, and I presented him— He had two Letters from the Prince Regent of England, which he delivered; one announcing the birth of a Son to the Duke of Cambridge and the other a daughter to the Duke of Kent— These ceremonies being quickly despatched the President spoke to me on several subjects of business. There are several appointments to be made— The Office of Register of Wills for the County of Washington is one— A list of all the Candidates and their recommendations were sent to the President. He named and remarked upon several of them; but came to no decision. Robert Brent has resigned the Office of Paymaster General— Frye, who married my wife’s Sister Caroline, is the Chief Clerk, in that division of the War Department; has performed all the duties of paymaster for the last fourteen Months; Mr Brent having been all the time confined by illness. Frye thinks himself in justice entitled to the appointment; but will not obtain it— Other, more powerful and more favoured Candidates stand in his way. Among the rest Lacock, the late Senator from Pennsylvania, who hashed up last Winter the Crambe bis cecta of accusation, against General Jackson, and the President, by his Report to the Senate on the Seminole War— The President spoke as if he was disgusted, at Lacock’s cringing for an Office, so immediately after making that Report; but as I suppose he is patronized by Crawford, and will be bolstered by Senatorial influence, I conclude he will before long get into some office, where he may intrigue with members of Congress, if even he should fail at present. As the President did not directly ask my opinion upon the case I did not give one. As to the Office of District Judge for the District of Maryland, I found he appeared to have made up his mind in favour of Judge
Bland. He did not indeed know that there was any other candidate— I told him of the applications and recommendations in behalf of Glenn, the District Attorney, and of the Letter of Mr Brackenridge offering his services in the Office. Brackenridge himself had been this Morning to my house, and had also called at the President’s and seen him, but had not asked for the appointment. I told the President of the objections made against Bland, and of the Deposition, which implicated him as personally interested in the Baltimore privateering Pirates. He directed me to send it over to him— He also gave me a Letter from the Selectmen of Boston to the Secretary of War, complaining of an insulting Letter from a Lieutenant James Scallan, to Franklin Dexter who delivered the 4th. of July town Oration, for an indirect fling in the Oration against General Jackson. The Oration, Scallan’s Letter, which Charges Dexter with having uttered an Untruth; and tells him where he is to be found—and another Letter from Scallan to the Selectmen disclaiming any intention of giving offence to any of those of Dexter’s hearers, who approved the Sentiment which had irritated him, were with the Letter— The President said the subject involved a variety of very delicate Considerations, and asked me to take and peruse the Papers, and give him my opinion upon what was to be done— At the Office, Mr Thompson the Secretary of the Navy came to enquire whether the President had determined to send the Hornet, and a special Messenger to Spain; and to ask if I would remove into the new public building opposite the Treasury— It had been understood till now, that the War and Navy Offices were to remove and I was to stay— But Mr Thompson now wishes to remain; and I agreed to go, provided I should have room enough for accommodation in the new Building. Lieutenant Finch came to renew an application to be appointed a special messenger to go to Europe— Mr Poletica, Mr Lomonossoff, and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were here this Evening.

12. V:15. I was engaged upon the draft of a very important despatch to Mr Forsyth; and the heat of the weather almost unremitted, with myriads of flies, bugs, and vermin of all filths, add to the discomforts, if not to the anxieties of this occupation. This morning Antoine killed a brownish snake two feet long, in the house at the foot of the Staircase, in the Entry. It was nigh two O’Clock when I went to the Office— Cardelli came with grievous complaints that Andrei had not only got him dismissed from working at the Capitol, but had traduced him as an Artist; pretending he was not regularly bred— He brought me a printed pamphlet which he had found at Franzoni’s, of a distribution of prizes at Rome in 1795. when he was only sixteen years old; and shewed me his name as having obtained one of the first prizes. This poor man distresses me, and really has not justice done him— At the Office I received despatches from A. Gallatin to 15. June. G. W. Erving was then at Paris. After I had returned home to dinner, Mr Van den Bergh came to me to ask, if he should obtain the appointment of Consul at Marseilles. He said he had come from New-York, and been waiting here several weeks for nothing else— He had brought such strong recommendations, that he had felt quite sure of success, had spoken of it, without reserve to his friends, and should be exceedingly mortified and disappointed, if he failed. But if that should happen, he wished to be considered a candidate for the next vacancy that may happen. And he wished an immediate decision, so that he might no longer be detained here in suspense. I promised to ask of the President a decision to-morrow— Mr and Mrs Frye called to see us after dinner, and Captain Biddle was here part of the Evening.

13. IV:30.Captain Read of the Hornet, called at my house: he wishes to return to Spain, and to be himself the bearer of the despatches to Mr Forsyth. I called at the President’s and there met Mr Calhoun. We spoke of the complaint of the Selectmen of Boston against Scallan, and the President asked my opinion— I said I had found a difficulty in settling principles in the case— Scallan, of whom I have no other knowledge than from this affair, had rashly and foolishly written an insulting Letter, for a Sentiment uttered on a public occasion, in an official capacity, under the corporate authority of the town of Boston, for which, it
being the place of my own residence, I had a peculiar regard, and respect. It was impossible for any one more strongly to disapprove this act, than I did; but a serious question with me was whether it was punishable by the President of the United States— The view taken of it in the Letter of the Selectmen, was a partial one—as a military offence against the civil authority— It was not a military Offence, merely because committed by a man holding a military commission— If punishable at all, it was as a breach of discipline, for which he should be tried by a Court Martial; but there was a Precedent, under the administration of my father, which shewed his opinion that the President of the United States could not with propriety take cognizance of it. I alluded to the complaint of John Randolph, against Reynolds, an Officer who insulted him at the Theatre, for a Speech in the House of Representatives in which he had insulted the army. Randolph complained of it as a breach of the privileges of the House; and the President sent the complaint to the House as the judges of their own privileges— Calhoun said his impression was that the President should instantly dismiss Scallan from the Service, without trial or further enquiry. There was no question about the facts— They were admitted by Scallans own Letters. It was not a case for trial by a Court martial, for it was a military offence against the civil authority—a case in which a Court Martial, had too much of their own feeling involved to be a competent tribunal, and which the President ought in the most summary and decisive manner to punish— The President’s authority to dismiss an Officer from the army was absolute, and he was not obliged to assign any reason for exercising it, and as to the Precedent, it did not apply; because the House of Representatives had the power to punish breaches of its privileges; but the Town of Boston had not— I then insisted upon the equity of the principle of hearing the other side— Admitted the absolute power of the President to dismiss an Officer, but insisted that it ought to be exercised with great discretion, and only for just and powerful reasons— That the Act of Scallan was punishable at Law or it was not— If it was, there was no occasion for the interposition of the President— If it was not, the President was required to punish without hearing him, a man who had violated no Law— And if the President was to assume a censorial power, without regard to the Law, over every man holding a military Commission, what would be the Condition of the army?— I referred to the publication last Spring in the National Intelligencer by General Jackson, or some of the Officers in his suite, against Lacock, and the report of the Committee of the Senate, and asked upon what principle they could have been overlooked, if Scallan was to be cashiered— The President then said that the subject was of so very delicate a nature that as a Precedent was to be settled he would take the opinion of the whole Cabinet and he directed me to pass the Papers over to Mr Crawford and Mr Thompson— The President determined that Captain Read should be sent with the despatches to Mr Forsyth, and that Mr Dodge should be appointed Consul at Marseilles— Mrs Clark dined at Mr W. S. Smith’s, and they all spent the Evening here— Heat overpowering— Fahrenheit at 93. and not a breath of air.

14. V:General Morris, Marshal of the New-York District, and his brother, and Mr R. Swartwout were here; arrived yesterday from New-York, through Baltimore; where it is said the yellow fever prevails— I called at the President’s to tell him, the draft of a despatch to Mr Forsyth would be ready Monday Morning. The President spoke of certain complaints against the conduct of Captain Biddle during his late service in the Ontario, upon the South-Sea—complaints which have become official, by communications from the Secretary of the State of Chile, to Mr Prevost, and transmitted by him. The President said he wished the charges against Captain Biddle to be considered by the Cabinet, first, as it concerned Biddle himself in which respect it would be proper to view it with great indulgence; but secondly with reference to principles, to be settled for the future;
and to be established by Instructions to the Commanders of all our armed vessels. He desired me to call at the Navy Department, and direct that Captain Biddle’s Report should be sent over to him, which I did. The heat continues almost suffocating— Fahrenheit at 94. Cardelli was here morning and Evening, to know what the President thought of his Busts, which he carried to his house to be viewed— I could not tell him. Mrs Adams, and Mrs Clark spent the Evening abroad, at W. S. Smith’s.

15. IV: At the dawn of day—I took Philip with me, and bathed in the Potowmack. Even at that hour, the weather was oppressively warm. Fahrenheit at 86. and the water of the river was tepid— I passed the remainder of the day at home— Finished the draft of the despatch to Forsyth, and wrote a very short Letter to my brother. This was all I could do, and three fourths of the day were wasted in idleness. Labour was to me impossible. The thermometer at 96. and the moment I sat down to write a heavy perspiration bursting from every pore, followed by prostration of strength, and imbecility both of body and mind. Captain Read of the Hornet was here; and I informed him the President had determined he should go with the despatches to Madrid. He proposed to leave the City to-morrow to go to New-York, and prepare for his departure. Forbes came and took the last sheet of the despatch to Forsyth to copy for to-morrow Morning. About six in the Evening there came up a heavy thunder-gust and showers, which partially tempered the raging heat of the day.

16. V: There were one or two heavy thunder showers in the Night, not sufficient however to clear up or dis-electrify the atmosphere— Judge Bland and William Pinkney were at my house this Morning. Bland was again at the Office— Some active friend had informed him of the representations made against him, and he has come with his friend W. Pinkney to put them down. He said that as to the appointment to the Office of judge, it was at the disposal of the President, and he should not be dissatisfied with any determination that he might come to upon it— But as his character had been assailed, he thought himself entitled to know what had been said against him and to vindicate himself— I told him the substance of all that had been charged against him; and particularly of the deposition, in the President’s possession— He utterly denied having had any interest in any of the Baltimore privateers, explained away his connections with Skinner, his intimacy with Karrick and Wright, his acquaintance with Commodore’s Taylor and Chaytor, and his private transactions at Buenos-Ayres and Chili, and admitted his partiality in favour of the South-Americans and their Cause. At the Office he asked first to see the deposition in question; and secondly to have a copy of it— I told him I would submit the question to the President, that he might perhaps consent that the substance of what related to him in the deposition should be read to him; but would probably doubt the propriety, of giving him at this time a copy of it— He brought me Letters from Rodney, and Graham to him, about his going to Chili. Pinkney called upon me, ostensibly about the settlement of his Accounts upon his late Missions to Naples and St. Petersburg; but I have no doubt he is here to crowd Bland upon the President as the District Judge for Maryland— I called upon Mr Thompson the Secretary of the Navy, at his lodgings at Strother’s— Found him quite unwell—on his bed— He gave me Scallan’s Letter to the Secretary at War, concerning his affair with Franklin Dexter and the Select-men of Boston— He appeared from the view that he took of the subject rather to concur with my opinion, than with that of Mr Calhoun. At the President’s I read to him the draft of a despatch to Mr Forsyth, which he approved in the main, but questioned some of the expressions as I knew he would, and which I inserted rather with the view that they should be finally expurged than retained. I have indeed found the expediency of introducing some such matter into every important draft; to absorb that portion of the objecting Spirit, which must find exercise upon something; and which if alloy be not provided for it to cast off, is apt to fall upon the pure metal itself. He desired me to pass the draft over to the other members of the Administration for their perusal, and to appoint a meeting at his house to pass upon it finally to-morrow, at one O’Clock— I gave it accordingly
to Mr Calhoun, requesting him to pass it over to Mr Thompson— At the Office, besides Mr Bland, I had long visits from Mr Pleasonton, and Captain O’Brien— As I was returning home, I was overtaken by a very heavy thunder-gust, and driven for shelter in to Mr W. S. Smith’s where I stopped nearly an hour. The rain having subsided I returned home, and just as I was crossing the Street to enter my house, there was a flash of lightening as sharp and a clap of thunder as violent as I ever witnessed— It must have struck within one hundred yards of me, and I distinctly felt a very slight shock like that from a common electrical chain in the joint of the thumb, with which I was holding the Umbrella over my head— The showers and thunder continued until after dark in the Evening.

17. V:Mr Morris the Marshal of New-York called at my house with a Mr Hogan, who came to apply for an appointment as Consul, either at one of the English manufacturing towns, or at Marseilles, or as Commercial Agent at the Havanna. Hogan is an Irishman who came to this Country 17 years ago with a fortune of £ 80000 Sterling, all of which he has lost— He has been 12 years a Citizen of the United States and wishes now to go and reside abroad without forfeiting that character— Mr W. Pinkney came to speak about the settlement of his Accounts— The questions relating to them, are for contingent expenses, at Naples, Vienna, and St. Petersburg; and also of the time, when his Salary was to commence—7. March 1810. the date of his Commission; or 15 May of the same year, when he was about to sail upon his Mission— I told him I would submit the questions to the determination of the President. He says that although he was very kindly and generously treated by the Government in those Missions, he has been more than ten thousand dollars out of pocket, by them— There was a Cabinet Meeting at the President’s, attended by Messrs.Crawford, Calhoun, and Wirt— Mr Thompson was too unwell to attend, and this Evening left the City to return to New-York. My despatch to Forsyth was read, and scrutinized— The passages which I had foreseen would be objected to were expunged, and two or three other slight alterations were suggested and adopted— This sifting, and revising of every important paper that I write, is not flattering, nor very agreeable; but the President submits his Messages to the same process.— There was little discussion upon the principles maintained in my despatch; though Mr Crawford and Mr Wirt started objections to the stress of my argument upon the unqualified promise of the King of Spain in Onis’s full-power to ratify whatever he should sign. There is no difference of opinion in the Cabinet, with regard to what is to be done, in the event of the Treaty’s not being ratified by Spain before the Meeting of Congress: but the field for diversities and oppositions will then arise— When the examination of the draft had been gone through, and the amendments made, the President directed that it should be copied, and despatched as soon as possible— The President referred also the subject of the complaint against Lieutenant Scallan by the Selectmen of Boston for Consideration— Mr Crawford gave no opinion upon it— Mr Wirt took stronger ground against the complaint than either Mr Thompson or I had taken— He said that the passage of Dexter’s Oration, which gave rise to the quarrel was a gross and outrageous insult upon the President and his Administration, as well as upon General Jackson and the army— That Scallan having been an Officer serving in that Campaign, felt it as a personal insult to himself, as every man of honour and sensibility would have felt it under the same circumstances. That he was perhaps wrong to notice it, precisely as he did; but it was under such provocation that the Selectmen should have considered it, as a personal affair between Dexter and Scallan with which they had nothing to do. That if the President of the United States, should make himself the judge and punisher of every fourth of July brawl, he would soon find occupation enough upon his hands without attending to any thing else— Mr Calhoun made no further observations upon the subject; nor did the President come to any determination concerning it— He proposed that a Proclamation should issue against an unlawful military expedition lately organized, and now in full operation against the Spanish Province of Texas bordering upon the Southern boundary of the United States— This was unanimously agreed to; and without discussion. I mentioned Judge Bland’s
request to see and have a copy of Sands’s deposition, affecting his character. This and several other depositions were communicated to the Government in Confidence— They were obtained, not for any purpose or with any view affecting Mr Bland, but generally for information concerning the Baltimore piratical privateers— But when I saw the influence at work to get Bland appointed precisely to this Office—the Judge to try those very offenders, I felt it a paramount duty to submit the deposition to the President— Within 24. hours Mr Bland was informed of it, and Post he comes, from Baltimore, with W. Pinkney the Counsel of all the Pirates, and the dictator of the Maryland Bar, from Annapolis, to carry the Office by Storm. On the question whether Bland should have a copy of the Deposition, Crawford volunteered an opinion that he should have it, and argued rather sophistically that there could be no breach of confidence in letting him have it. The President without deciding the point gave the Deposition to Mr Wirt, to examine and give his opinion— All the discussions were smooth, and perfectly amicable— We all dined at the President’s. W. Pinkney, T. Morris and R. Swartwout were there. Mrs Monroe was unwell, and did not appear— Mr G. Hay spoke of various things, and among the rest of the complaint of the Selectmen of Boston against Scallan. Hay married the President’s eldest daughter, and is one of his most confidential friends and extra-Constitutional advisers— He is in outward form a Republican of the sternest Virginian stamp; but in inward substance, a man of virtue sufficiently accommodating to ask favours and use flattery, with a deportment not absolutely rude. He has twice applied to me in writing to appoint his Son to Office in the Department, which I could not possibly give him, without gross injustice to the Clerks now in it— He is a lawyer of eminent talents and a Member of the Senate of Virginia. He is a most useful friend to the President, and devoted to him with unbounded zeal. He has been lately publishing in the Richmond Enquirer three elaborate numbers signed Hortensius, canvassing the decision of the Supreme Court of the United States, given last Winter, that the Legislatures of the separate States have not a Constitutional right to tax the Bank of the United States— His argument is that the decision of the Court was right, and the reasoning upon which they gave it was wrong— The object is to produce acquiescence in the decision, and to guard against the application of the reasoning to the controverted right of Congress to appropriate money for internal improvements— He asked Calhoun to day, what he thought of Hortensius N. 3. and complained that it had not excited much public attention— Calhoun told him he did not concur with the opinions of Hortensius. I walked home from the President’s with Calhoun— Weather very sultry, with thunder and rain— Mrs Adams was very ill this Evening.

18. V:Mrs Adams continued ill, all Night; but was recovering, this day. Messrs.Bland, Worthington and Hogan were at my house this Morning; and Bland afterwards again at my Office. I read to him the parts of Sands’s deposition which related to himself. Sands was one of the owners of the privateer which perhaps of all others has committed the greatest excesses— His deposition names all the owners; charges Bland with having frequently been at their Meetings, held at his, Sands’s house where Taylor lived, and declares the opinion, founded on a variety of facts, that Bland had a pecuniary interest in the privateer, covered under the name of W. Wright— It relates particulars of an occurrence at Skinner’s, which if true would not leave a doubt of his knowledge at least of the privateering transactions— It states also that Commodore Taylor (the man who first commanded the Privateer) had told Sands, that Bland, at Buenos Ayres had offered Taylor, a passage in the Congress Frigate— But that another of the Commissioners had objected, and Taylor had been obliged to take out his baggage, which was already on board— Bland declared that it was all slander; that there was not a particle of truth in the charges; that he never had any interest, in any shipping concern whatever, that he never knew where Taylor lived, at Baltimore; that Skinner, Karrick and Wright, would all deny the fact of his having been at their meetings, and that he had left the Congress Frigate, at Montevideo, and never returned to her— He was exceedingly agitated and distressed— The workings of
Passion upon his Countenance, were stronger than I ever witnessed on a human face, not tortured with Physical pain— It alternately flushed and turned pale, while his lip quivered, and his eye turned as if instinctively away from the scrutiny of inspection. My own feelings were deeply harrowed in sympathy for him; and yet from the mode of his denials, the impression left upon my mind was that if not interested in the privateer he knew more of all the transactions than he was willing to avow— It seemed as if there was mental reservation, in all that he said— His general denial was positive and explicit enough; but his denials of specific facts were faint, and rather evasive— It was rather an assertion of other facts, which seemed incompatible with the fact charged, than the denial of the fact itself. I told him before reading to him the extract of Sands’s deposition, that although the witness’s name could not be mentioned to him, the very facts charged in his testimony, might probably disclose who he was— And after I had read, though he declared he never knew where Taylor lived, he did not deny that he knew who it was, that made the deposition— In the morning at my house, he urged with extreme earnestness that as his name had been brought forward as a Candidate, if he should not be appointed the general impression of the public would be that the Executive considered him guilty, which would be ruin to his good name. Now this conclusion was not sound, and I reasoned with him against, it, but without effect— At my house he intreated that the President would suspend the appointment, until the trials shall be gone through, and he, could have time and opportunity to vindicate his character— I made the proposal to the President; but he said that to suspend the appointment, would be in some sort to give a pledge, that if the mere fact of personal interest in the privateers should be disproved, Bland should be appointed; which pledge it would be improper to give— In the midst of Bland’s exasperation he broke out in an invective against the Spanish Consul at Baltimore, and the Abbe Correa the Portuguese Minister, for their activity, in the prosecution of these Privateers, and said he had reason to believe they had used subornation of perjury against him— I told him that as to their activity, it was not only to be expected from them on this occasion, but was enjoined upon them as a duty— But what motive could they have for fixing a groundless charge upon him? And I asked him whether entertaining such opinions of them, he thought himself an impartial Judge, between them and their adversaries? He said he did not think he should be— He finally left me in the deepest dejection; and saying that he knew not what he could do. Mr Worthington came to ask answers, upon certain extraordinary claims for the settlement of his Accounts and upon a direct question, which since his return from South-America he has put; in a Letter to me; whether it is the President’s intention to employ him in public office again— With regard to the Accounts the President said he would examine the claim, and I directed the papers to be looked up and sent to him— As to the further employment of Worthington, he said he stood upon the footing of other citizens, but was not fit for any appointment, which required the exercise of discretion— A quality in which Worthington, by his pretension of making a Treaty at Buenos-Ayres and by his conduct generally had proved himself to be remarkably deficient. Mr Hogan came to press for the appointment of Commercial Agent at the Havanna. The President had not remarked that there was a prior application with strong recommendations, which it was therefore necessary to lay before him— I directed the papers to be sent to him— Hogan to strengthen his claim, puffed himself to me, by pretences of having great and powerful political friends and connections; which will never be of the value of a straw to the United States— And he assured me that he was the cause of the Treaty of Ghent’s being made, by writing a Letter to a friend of his in England, which was laid before the British Cabinet, and produced a total Revolution in their views and opinions— And they said it contained more important and correct information concerning this Country, than all the despatches of all the Ministers they had ever had here. The President spoke again about Mr Lacock as a Candidate for the Office of Pay-Master General, and asked my opinion whether the considerations which he had enumerated
the other day against his appointment, ought not to prevail— I told him that they appeared to me decisive; and I thought it even strange that under such Circumstances, he should even suffer his name to be mentioned— The President said he did not know that he had—but a friend of his had mentioned him— Tis probably Roberts— I was at the office till past six— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith spent the Evening here.

19. V:45. I had Mr Worthington and Mr Hogan again at my house this Morning; I told Worthington that as to his being employed again, the President had observed that his pretensions would stand upon the same ground as those of other Citizens; but there was at present no office vacant which would be suitable to him— He appeared quite nettled at this, and said he had thought his zealous and faithful services, in the office which he had filled gave him claims to further employment not common to other citizens in general— That there seemed to be some fatality attending our affairs with South-America. He would wish to know whether his conduct had not given satisfaction to the Government. I told him that the President wished to pass no censure upon him— None had been passed; nor would any disapprobation have been expressed to him had he not asked this question— But I could not in candour withhold an answer. The President had not been pleased with his assuming to make a Treaty at Buenos-Ayres, for which he had no authority, and had thus compromitted this Government in its foreign relations. He said he had not pretended to be authorised to make a Treaty. That I had so stated in my Correspondence with Mr de Forrest, and he had supposed his conduct on that occasion had been fully explained to the satisfaction of the Government— And he had thought of an appointment to Constantinople, as one for which the Government might have occasion and which would suit him— He concluded by saying he would call again upon the President. Hogan came to make another push for his appointment. A Mr Morrison brought me a Letter of Introduction from Mr Nathaniel Pope at Kaskaskia, Illinois— At the President’s— He told me that it was General Mason of Georgetown who had given information to Mr Bland of Sands’s deposition against him— He also said he had thought of offering the office of District Judge to J. F. Mercer, though he did not know whether he would accept it— The other candidates, besides Mr Bland, were Glenn, the District Attorney, whom he thought incompetent, and Brackenridge; a younger man than Bland, at variance with him, and whose appointment might seem an act of hostility to him— The President also decided that Hogan should be appointed commercial agent at the Havanna— Mr M’Culloch the Collector of Baltimore called at my Office with S. H. Smith— Received a budget of despatches from R. Rush, C. Hughes, A. H. Everett, and G. W. Campbell— Mr and Mrs Frye, with Thomas Hellen, and Robert Buchanan dined with us— Forbes was here after dinner— We spent the Evening at W. S. Smith’s.

20. IV:45. My time is so continually absorbed that it is scarcely possible to keep my diary free from arrears. At the President’s I met Mr Crawford. The President had intended to go next Monday to his seat in Loudoun County; but has postponed his departure for some days. Mr Cathcart came to the Office about his Accounts, and to repeat the request for an advance of money, which I have many times informed him I could not make. He complained that I had delayed reporting to Congress upon his Petition which has been referred by the House of Representatives to me— I told him the Report had been delayed from a reluctance to report against him; and an impossibility to report with a clear Conscience in his favour— He flew into a passion, as if it was a reflection upon his character to intimate that he would advance an unfounded claim— I told him that was not the ground upon which it could be placed— The validity of a claim was not to be tested by the character of the claimant, but upon its own Merits— I promised him however to Report to the House upon his Petition, at the Commencement of the next Session, and in the mean time consented that he should take his papers to see if he could obtain any thing by a new examination of the Auditor and Comptroller— Mr Poletica the Russian Minister, his Secretary Mr Lomonossoff, and Mr Bailey were at my house this Evening— Bailey wishes for a leave of absence from the Department, for some weeks— Forbes has requested the same permission.

21. V:15.Mr Van den Bergh late candidate for the Office of Consul at Marseilles was here and took leave, being on his return to New-York— He spoke also of the Consulate of St. Salvador in Brazil, and of any of the Consulates on the Barbary Coast, as objects which would be agreeable to him. Judge Bland came with a number of papers which he has procured at Baltimore, to discredit the reputation of Sands and his deposition against him. They do entirely discredit him. I firmly believe that Sands’s deposition is false in every particular that he states, respecting Bland; yet my opinion is unimpaired that Bland is one of the last men in the United States fit to be appointed as the Judge of those very persons and crimes with which he has been thus charged with participating. Bland said his only object in procuring these papers was to restore himself in the President’s good opinion and mine. I took the papers to the President, with whom I found Mr Crawford. He was proposing the appointment of a Captain for the Revenue Cutter at Baltimore, for which several persons were recommended, and among the rest a man named Webster, who not three Months ago was a Lieutenant of a Buenos Ayres privateer— This man too is now here to drive his own appointment in person— Crawford himself very manifestly leaned towards appointing him, though he was wary as a Jesuit in his mode of recommending him; for he alternately mentioned the recommendations of a competitor, with so much force and candour, that it had every semblance of impartiality. The President wavered a long time, and repeatedly made so very light of the man’s connection with the piratical privateers that I strongly apprehended he would decide in his favour— As this appointment was not of the resort of my Department, I said nothing— The President did not ask my opinion, though both he and Crawford continued long the Conversation, it appeared to me, with an anxiety to elicit some remark from me. I was determined not to speak unless required, and the President finally though somewhat irresolutely said he thought it would be safest to appoint the other man. Crawford acquiesced; and yet I shall wait to see who will at last get the Commission. Baltimore, upon privateering and Banking is rotten to the heart. The Revenue Cutter, is the only check upon the movements of the Pirates in our waters— Beard the late Captain, connived at them and favoured them in gross violation of his duty— He has been removed, and now one of the Pirates is thrust forward to take his place; recommended by almost every one whose recommendation has any influence, that is by the whole gang of Pirates, and their abettors— The President had also a Letter just received from W. Pinkney since his return to Annapolis, pushing again for the appointment of Bland, in a manner which I consider as very indelicate. Pinkney, the standing Counsel for all the Pirates; who by brow-beating and domineering over the Courts, and by paltry pettifogging law-quibbles has saved all their necks from the richly merited halter, palms upon the President for their future judge, a man strongly though I believe falsely charged with being their accomplice, but whose connections with them have been so close, intimate and notorious, that it is as impossible he should be an impartial judge upon them, as that he should have escaped the suspicion of being privy to their misdeeds. I left Bland’s papers with the President, who will send them back to me to-morrow. At the Office I prepared the despatches for Mr Forsyth, and sent them to Captain Read of the Hornet at New-York. With Mrs Clark, and Mary Hellen, I dined at Mr Frye’s. Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith and Forbes were there. Mrs Adams being unwell did not go.— Forbes brought me home in his Gig.

22. VI:Mr Bland was here again this Morning— I told him that I had read the papers which he brought yesterday, and had left them with the President, who had also promised to read them. I was fully satisfied that no credit was due to Sands’s deposition against him. He then told me that the Grand-Jury last November had indicted several persons upon Sands’s testimony; but in May last they had indicted Sands himself. Bland repeated that his only object had been to clear himself of the charge against him in the Deposition; and asked if there was any thing else, that he could disprove— If there was any thing behind— I told him there was nothing in any responsible shape nothing to which any name was attached— But there were and had been floating rumours and suspicions, even before he went to South-America, which had arisen from his known and avowed attachment to the South-Americans
and their cause. He said that he had always entirely disapproved of the Baltimore privateering; and had deeply regretted that his kinsman, Mr Skinner was accused of being concerned in them— He is to call again at my Office to-morrow, for his papers— The two brothersVail were here, and offered their services if any extra copying should be wanted at the Department. Thierry the French Charge d’Affaires, brought me a Letter from Mr Hyde de Neuville, the Minister, who is at New-York still— I told him I would answer it, if I could find time to-morrow; but that I should expect to see Mr de Neuville myself at New-York, next Thursday— I went after dinner and spent an hour at Mr Middleton’s— Mrs Adams being yet unwell did not go with me. I brought back to Commodore Decatur’s, a young Midshipman named Buller, who was in the Ontario with Captain Biddle— One of Mr Middleton’s sons was on board in the same capacity. Decatur and his wife were walking, before the door of his house, when I stopped and sat Buller down.

23. V:30.Captain O’Brien came this Morning to my house, to enquire if the President had decided upon his claim of remuneration for making a Peace for the United States with Tripoli, near twenty-five years ago: because he said he understood I was clearing out, to steer to the North East, and was to get under weigh to-morrow-Morning. Dr Thornton, and Dr Allison also called upon me, to ask if the President had come to a determination, upon their project; which is that Thornton should be appointed an agent to South-America, and that Allison should be superintendent of the Patent Office, in his stead— Thornton has long set his heart upon this agency to South-America.— He is a man of some learning, and much ingenuity; of quick conception and lively wit; entirely destitute of Judgment, discretion and common sense. He has been nearly twenty years Superintendent of the Patent Office; a place principally made by Mr Madison to put him in it, and there has scarcely issued from it during the whole time a Patent, for any invention, but the Doctor had a counter claim, as the inventor of the same thing himself. He has a fine taste in Architecture, and a real turn for mechanical invention; but no steadiness to pursue any thing to a useful result— He has very foolishly made himself a fanatical partizan for the revolutionary South-Americans; and has committed the grossest indiscretions in pursuit of this ignis fatuus—to the extent of pretending to negotiate between M’Gregor and the Government of the United States; and publishing under a fictitious signature in the National Intelligencer the substance of the Negotiation— The Doctor is a Horse-racer too, and often boasts that the South-Americans have repeatedly offered to appoint him a Coll. of Cavalry in their service. He considers himself as the principal author of the South-American Revolution, and that all the principal measures of the Patriots have been adopted at his suggestion— In the course of my life I have met with very few men of minds at once so active, intelligent, and weak. Yet he is withal a man of good intentions, and generally harmless deportment. As Superintendent of the Patent Office, he is useful; and fully competent to the place— Though by his interfering pretensions he gives great offence to many of the Patentees. As for the agency to South-America, the President considers him utterly unfit for any such office, and will never appoint him to it; but with him as with other claimants for preposterous things, it is one of the duties of my Office to temper refusal with politeness: the inconvenience of which is that tenacious applicants, return to the attack like flies in dog days; and never will take no, for an answer. Allison is an old Clergyman, who was a chaplain in our army during the Revolutionary War, and has been several years Chaplain to the House of Representatives in Congress— He is also an inventor and patentee; and has a competent knowledge of mechanics, and is almost as zealous in favour of the South-American Patriots, as Thornton himself. I told them that I believed the President did not contemplate sending any Agent to South-America, at present. At the President’s I found Mr Crawford and Mr Calhoun— Webster was again on the tapis for the appointment of Captain of the Revenue Cutter at Baltimore; and Crawford was taking a second decision of the President— I collected from what was said that the President adhered to his determination of Saturday. When he takes his bias he is seldom to be moved from it; and yet I am not confident of the result of this appointment. I read
the draft of a circular Letter to the Ministers of the United States in Europe, concerning the new Instructions just despatched to Mr Forsyth— The draft was approved. At the Office Mr Bland came and took his papers; and by the President’s direction I wrote him a Letter, declaring the President’s full persuasion, that the imputations against Bland, of having had a personal interest in the piratical privateers were utterly without foundation. Mr Worthington came for the settlement of his Accounts, and to insist upon what he considered as in some sort his right, of having another appointment— This man, who is a shallow, prating, vain and silly fellow, to give himself an air of consequence at Buenos-Ayres, without a shadow of authority undertook to make a Treaty with Pueyrredon’s Government, in which there was a stipulation for the mutual admission of Consul’s— In consequence of which Pueyrredon sent De Forest here as Consul General— And when in Chili, Worthington became part owner of the Lautaro a ship of War, manned chiefly by desertions from American vessels; commanded by an American Captain, and very successful in war against the Spaniards. All this he now considers as quite justifiable; says he sees nothing in his conduct to disapprove, and thinks it quite extraordinary that he should be dismissed from the public service, as if he had not been faithful to his trust— I heard him with composure, upon these topics, about half an hour, and he closed by observing that he must either return to the practice of Law, for which he had no relish, or go and bury himself in Kentucky; intimating that he was not disposed, however great his provocation, to take part with any malcontents against the administration— I took no notice of this hint, but said I had readily heard all his remarks in defence of his own conduct; thought it would be useless for me to enter upon a discussion with him concerning it— I would remind him however that no censure had been passed upon him; and that in this Country, service in public Office gave no claim to further employment. I mentioned to him the case of many persons employed as Ministers of the United States abroad, who after returning home, were in private life, though nothing in their conduct had been liable to censure— He made no reply; though my doctrine was apparently too unpalateable to obtain his assent. On going away he gave me his hand with much assumed cordiality and a smiling countenance; and will now go, and as often as he can, abuse the administration in the newspapers; occasionally renewing his applications for a new appointment. I was engaged at the Office in preparations for departure till near seven in the Evening— Mr and Mrs Frye, Forbes, and W. S. Smith came and took leave. Poletica had called at the Office, and told me that Lomonossoff being unwell they had postponed their departure till Wednesday. Mrs Adams this Evening concluded to go with us.

24. IV:30. At six O’Clock this morning, with my wife, Mrs Susan B. Clark my niece, and her infant daughter, I took the Stage for Baltimore— There were several other passengers in the Stage, but none whom we knew. Among them was a young man, just from St. Louis in the Missouri Territory, in 27 days— We breakfasted at the house formerly kept by Ross, and at 2. O’Clock P.M. arrived at Baltimore. Dined at Gadsby’s tavern, Sign of the Indian Queen, which is now taken upon a lease for four years, by Barnum, former keeper of the Exchange Coffee house at Boston; who is to take possession to-morrow. At five in the afternoon we embarked in the Steam-boat United-States, Captain Trippe, and arrived just before Midnight at Frenchtown. From thence we proceeded immediately in a Post-Coach to Newcastle, where we arrived at four O’Clock in the Morning.

25. Embarked at Newcastle in the Steam-boat Baltimore, and at half past nine arrived at Philadelphia. Among the passengers with us from Baltimore was Mr Van den Bergh, and Dr Allison, with his Son’swidow and her four children. The son was in one of the public Offices at Washington, and died there a few weeks since— I intended to have proceeded immediately, on the Journey, but the Ladies preferred stopping till to-morrow Morning at Philadelphia and we went to Miss Shinn’s N. 30. North third Street. I called soon after at the Bank of the United States, and finished my business there— The Cashier, Smith introduced me to Mr Cheves the President of the Bank, with whom I had some conversation upon the affairs of the Bank. He
shewed me Letters which he had just received from Mr Gallatin and from General Cadwalader sent by the Bank to London and Paris, as their Agent to make a loan for three years of the money which is to be paid of the Louisiana Loan. He has succeeded in effecting the loan. Cheves said that it was the Bank of the United States alone which could preserve this Country from a paper Currency, and they could certainly accomplish it by persevering in the system of restriction upon the issues of Bank paper which he has established, and if it has the support of the Government. He wished particularly that the President should introduce a paragraph, favourable to the Bank in his Message to Congress, at the opening of their next Session, and that the Secretary of the Treasury should take a similar notice of it in his annual Report on the finances— I called at Mr Ewing’s, and met Connell and afterwards Meredith in the Street— Connell came and spent two or three hours with me after dinner— He is a Director of the Bank of the United States, and I found him extremely dissatisfied with its present management, and particularly with Mr Cheves, who he says has an overwhelming power of words; but is not a practical man, and is ridiculously ignorant of some of the most common principles of Banking. Full of self-importance, overbearing, impatient of contradiction, and construeing every the slightest opposition to any of his measures into personal enmity against him— His measures had been of no service to the Bank— They were to be sure safe, and might perhaps be convenient to the Government; but they were ruinous to the interest of the Stockholders; and if persisted in, there would be no dividend, for three years to come. He gave me a great variety of details concerning the affairs of the Bank, and said there were a majority of the Directors against Cheves, but scarcely any of them knew anything about Banking, and none of them would assume the responsibility of opposing him— There is to be a general meeting of the Stockholders in November, when Connell thinks there will be warm debating among them; and a strong opposition to the re-election of Cheves as President. Biddle he says is the only one of the Directors, who supports Cheves in all his views, but Cheves himself treats the Directors as if they were mere Machines to carry his purposes into effect. Every thing is prepared for them, and discussion scarcely tolerated. Indeed if this system was to be persevered in, it would be the interest of the Stockholders to surrender their Charter and take back their capital— Ewing came and spent an hour with me this Evening— I engaged passage for us in the Steam-boats and stages by the way of Bordentown, and Amboy, to New-York.

26. V: At six this Morning we embarked in the Steam-Boat Pennsylvania, Captain Wellington— The wind and tide were both strong against us, and it was within a quarter of an hour of one O’Clock when we landed at Bordentown, although the distance from Philadelphia, is only 27 miles— The boiler of the engine was damaged too— The Boat stopped at Bristol to land, and take in passengers; and Cristiani came on board, with a budget of his own music which he has had engraved at Philadelphia— He was taking it down to Miss Hopkinson, to whom he is giving lessons. He gave me two of the pieces—a President Monroe’s March; and a Song; the words of which were written by Mr Middleton’seldest son; a lawyer, residing at Philadelphia. Cristiani told me that he had sent one of the Marches to Mr Monroe, and was somewhat surprized that he had not received an answer. At Bordentown, we found Post-Coaches ready for us, and came in just four hours to Amboy, where the Steam-Boat was waiting for us— We immediately embarked, and landed at ten in the Evening at New-York. We took lodgings at the City Hotel— As my project was to proceed at 8 O’Clock to-morrow Morning in the Steam-Boat, to New-Haven, and I was desirous of seeing Mr Hyde de Neuville, I went out in search of him; first to Mr Cruger’s according to the direction given me by Thierry, which was erroneous, and then to the Count d’Espinville’s, the French Consul’s. I roused him from his bed, and held a Dialogue with him, standing at the door of his house; and he in his night-cap, with his head out of the Chamber-window; like the Scene in Moliere’s George Dandin. He told me that Mr de Neuville, was very anxious to see me, and had waited until six O’Clock this Evening in the City; but had then gone seven Miles into the Country. I told him I must leave the City at 8 O’Clock to-
morrow Morning, and desired him to say to Mr de Neuville how much I regretted having missed the opportunity of seeing him here. After returning to my lodgings I concluded to stay here till next Monday instead of going on to-morrow.

27. VI: Between seven and eight O’Clock this Morning, Mr Hyde de Neuville came in to my apartments at the City Hotel. The Count d’Espinville the Consul, had sent an Express for him into the Country, in the Night, and he came immediately to the City. It was however already too late for us to go in the Steam Boat for New-Haven this morning; and I persisted in the determination to wait till Monday. I had an hour’s Conversation with Mr de Neuville, and a second, when he came again at one O’Clock— He shewed me a Letter from Mr Onis, dated 6. June at Liverpool, immediately after his arrival there. He had nothing however very recent from Europe. He is undoubtingly confident that the king of Spain will ratify the Treaty of 22. February last; an opinion in which I do not concur. De Neuville himself had the Grand Cross and Ribband of the order of Isabella, which includes the title of Excellency, bestowed upon him by the King of Spain, for his services in the Negotiation; but this was at the first moment when the Treaty was received as an advantageous bargain to Spain; and before the party against it had obtained the ascendancy. I told Mr de Neuville the measures which the President has determined to recommend to Congress in this case; and the substance of the Instructions just despatched to Mr Forsyth. The Hornet, Captain Read, sailed with them from this place on the 24th.— De Neuville said he had concluded what the course of this Government, in the Event of the Non-ratification of the Treaty would be; and had written more than a month since to his Government, that Florida, would be occupied— He spoke also of the observations upon the eighth Article of the Treaty, which I lately sent him, and expressed the wish that the part of them referring to his telling me that Mr Onis made it a point of honour that the Article should be so drawn as to annul the grants, because he had been charged with being interested in them, might not be published— He admitted that he had said something like it, but said the expression of Onis’s having made it a point of honour was too strong— That Mr Onis certainly knew, that the grants were annulled; but that he should make a point of honour of annulling them, would have been a violation of his Instructions, which no personal purpose of vindicating his character could have warranted. That much of what he had said to me had been confidential, and rather as from man to man; than as from a Minister to the Secretary of State; and that it would be extremely painful to him to see anything published as coming from him which would tend to injure Mr Onis, and compromise him with his own Government. I told him that those observations would probably not be published, and I would endeavour to preserve from publication, everything which might be disagreeable to him. That the observation, to the publication of which he objected had been of some importance, in reconciling us to a modification of the Article; because its tendency was to convince us that Mr Onis had no design to protect those grants or to raise any question concerning them. That throughout the whole transaction, his, de Neuville’s conduct had been candid and honourable; but that of Mr Onis had been far otherwise— And the colouring which he had attempted to give to the Article of the Treaty in question, to Mr Poletica, and others in Philadelphia, could be designated by no other terms than as positive falsehood. Statements which he not only knew to be false, but which would be contradicted by his own written declarations. De Neuville said that perhaps Poletica ought not to have told what Onis had said to him; and that we ought to make some allowances for Onis’s situation. He saw that Casa-Yrujo the Minister under whose Instructions he had concluded had been disgraced— He was going home himself, under no small anxiety what his own reception would be— He wished therefore to secure some possible retreat for himself, and seized hold of this, to say to the king, that it was a point upon which he might if he pleased refuse the ratification of the Treaty, but then he will point out the consequences in such a manner, that the king will see there is no other safe alternative, and I might rely upon it, the Treaty would be ratified.
I said I wished it might, but had no expectation that it would. So far as related to the benefits derived by the United States from the Treaty, I felt little concern; being satisfied, that we shall get more without the Treaty than with it. But what I wanted was mutual satisfaction, good humour, and harmony of purpose, with Spain and France— And I was not desirous that the king of Spain, and kingly Government in general should be held up to the world in that odious and detestable light in which this affair would expose them if the Treaty should not be ratified— De Neuville also spoke to me about his project for a Consular Convention; and the claim of the French Consul at Philadelphia, to take possession of the property of a Frenchman lately deceased there— He says that Letters of Administration had been granted in opposition to this claim to an American Citizen; but there was yet time for the Consul to appeal. I told him I had begun an answer to his Letter enquiring what were the Powers of foreign Consuls in this Country; but had left it unfinished, on receiving accounts of a Judgment by a mere tribunal of Commerce against R. G. Beasley, our Consul at Havre, in direct opposition, to a Letter from the late Minister of the Interior, L’Ainé, and also contrary to that abstract, from the Instructions to the French Consuls, which he had sent me; describing the privileges which French Consuls might claim in foreign Countries, on the principle that they are allowed to foreign Consuls in France. It had immediately occurred to me that if in France a judicial Court of the very lowest order a mere Tribunal of Commerce, could adjudicate in direct opposition to the decisions of a Minister of State, on a point of consular privileges, I could certainly give no general definition of such privileges, as of right belonging to foreign Consuls here, which would not in like manner be liable to reversal by the sentence of a judicial tribunal— And caution was the more incumbent upon me, as besides the general privileges, attributed to Consuls, by the Laws of Nations, which were very indefinite and unsettled, I could only state that foreign Consuls enjoyed here, the same rights which the Laws of the United States authorized our Consuls to exercise in foreign Countries— But even this would only be an inference of mine, which our judicial Courts might contradict, as those in France had overthrown the decision of the Minister L’Ainé— One thing however I could tell him was, that Foreign Consuls here were subject only to the Jurisdiction of the highest tribunal, of the Nation, the Supreme Court of the United States. He said that L’Ainé’s decision had certainly been wrong; but it was his own fault. He ought to have had it given in the form of a royal ordinance— Mr Gahn the Swedish Consul, called upon me early this Morning, and afterwards came and introduced to me Baron Stackelberg, who has just arrived here, as Chargé d’Affaires from Sweden; he brought me an Official Letter of Introduction from the Count d’Engeström the Swedish Minister of Foreign Affairs, and one of Introduction from Chr. Hughes our Secretary at Ghent, and now Charge d’Affaires at Stockholm— Coll. Hawkins came to attend the funeral of Coll. Constant late an officer of our army, who died in this house yesterday and was buried from it this Morning. Young W. Gracie and W. S. Clarkson were likewise here. Mr Astor and another Gentleman called; but I was at the time very busily engaged with Mr Hyde de Neuville; and could not see them— I have some apprehension, they were offended at being told I was engaged— I passed the day at my lodgings, with the exception of a solitary walk round the City, and on the battery towards Evening.

28. VI: A Mr Carter, son in Law and Executor, of the late Isaac Clason came to me, to make enquiries concerning one of the void grants of Land in Florida; R. Hackley, owed Clason a large sum of money, and offers a part of this land in discharge of the debt— It is part of the grant to Vargas, which is null and void even by the date, and without a question on the part of Spain. Carter had written to me three or four Months since on the subject, but as I did not feel at liberty to give information partially concerning the Treaty, I had left his Letter unanswered— I told him so this day, and added that Hackley’s offer of the Land was worth nothing, and the grant to which he referred, mere waste paper— But that Hackley had claims upon the Spanish Government
which if the Treaty should be ratified, might be provided for, and enable him to satisfy his Creditors here. The weather was lowering all the Morning; but after waiting till eleven O’clock as it did not rain, I crossed the East River in the Steam ferry-boat to Brooklyn; there took a horse and gig, and went to Mr Rufus King’s at Jamaica, Long Island; on the road I was overtaken, by a very heavy Shower of rain— I found Mr King at home, alone. His residence is twelve Miles from Brooklyn, over a fine turnpike Road, which has been made since I was last here—that was in August 1785. when I visited here the Mother of Coll. W. S. Smith. I dined with Mr King, and we sat till six, in the Evening; conversing with perfect freedom upon various topics, chiefly political. I then returned to Brooklyn, recrossed the ferry, and came back to my lodgings at the City Hotel— Mr and Madame de Neuville, and Mr and Mrs Cruger with whom they reside had visited Mrs Adams in the course of the day; and also Major and Mrs Satterlee Clark, who were lodging at the same house, and in chambers next to ours.

29. VI: I occupy as much time, as I have at leisure in bringing up the arrears of this Diary, which have arisen since I left Washington; and was thus engaged all this Morning, till W. S. Clarkson came, and I went with him to the Trinity Church and heard a Sermon from Mr Brownell, bishop elect of Connecticut. It was edifying enough, but not remarkable for eloquence— After Church I called on Mr Thompson, the Secretary of the Navy, at his house, and found him yet quite unwell, with a slow fever— W. S. Clarkson dined with us; and Mr de Neuville came and sat two hours with me after dinner. I paid visits at Mr Astor’s, and at Coll. Trumbull’s neither of whom was at home— We walked in the Evening on the Battery, and Mrs Adams received visits from Mrs and Miss Thompson, with Mr Stoughton, a Son of the Spanish Consul, and another Gentleman. The day was very warm, and the Evening short.

30. V: From the time of rising until breakfast, I wrote, about two hours; and at eight this morning we embarked in the Steam-Boat Connecticut, Captain Bunker— As we were walking down to the Slip we were overtaken, by Mrs John Gray, of Boston, who embarked with us. We also found Mr Boardman of Boston, a passenger in the boat, and a son of Mr Benjn Austin, a Surgeon in the Navy. The company was less numerous than usual; about thirty. W. S. Clarkson was at the boat and took leave of us. The weather was cool and the day remarkably fine. We arrived at New-Haven at the Dusk of the Evening, between seven and eight O’Clock—and immediately passed into the Steam-Boat Fulton, Captain Law— There I met Coll. Trumbull, who with his wife was returning to New-York, from a visit to his Sister in Connecticut. After exchanging Boats, I soon retired to bed— The day had been to me a dull one— To avoid being encumbered with superfluous baggage, I had avoided taking with me a single book; but I have very repeatedly felt the want of one since I left home. Lord Byron’s Mazeppa, and the second Series of Salmagundi were this day on board the Boat, and I was obliged to content myself with them.

31. V: I was awakened, about four O’Clock, by the noise made on the arrival of the Boat, at New-London; but I did not immediately rise— The Boat soon proceeded, and when I rose I found Mr Henry Channing had come on board at New-London— He had written me a Letter some Months since, requesting an opportunity thus to meet me, and I had given him a rendezvous in this boat. It was to have been last Friday; but as I missed coming at that time, he had concluded that I should come this day, and was on board to meet me. We arrived about seven O’Clock at Norwich, and breakfasted at the Tavern there. Mr Gray, Mr Boardman, and all our other fellow Passengers left us there to proceed by the way of Providence to Boston— I concluded to come by the other way, commonly called the middle road, through Canterbury, Ashford, Pomfret, Thompson Douglas, Uxbridge, Mendon, Bellingham, Medway, Medfield to Dedham, where we arrived at ten O’Clock in the Evening. We had the Post Coach at first to ourselves, with Mr Channing, who accompanied us only as far as Canterbury. We dined at Thompson, 51 Miles from Boston. The Stage, through Providence had gone through Dedham, just before we arrived there. Our Stage went into Boston this Night but we left it at Dedham, where we stopped to lodge. I had conversation with Mr Channing upon various topics, but his principal object was to inform me of certain misconduct of a man named Alexander Richards, Collector at Ogdensburg.
Day— First three weeks, as the prior Month’s— The last week travelling.
